Package fr.sorbonne_u.components

Interface ComponentI

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractComponent, ClientComponent, ClientSideExample, ConcurrentMapComponent, ContinuationExamples, DynamicAssembler, DynamicComponentCreator, DynamicURIConsumer, DynamicURIProvider, GestionnaireReseau, IntegerFilter, IntegerPipeline, IntegerProcessor, Node_AccessPoint, Node_Routing, Node_Terminal, Ordinateur, PC_Terminal, PingPongPlayer, PipelineClient, RandomValueProvider, ReflectionClient, ReflectionServer, ServerComponent, ServerSideExample, Tablette, TesterComponent, URIConsumer, URIConsumer, URIProvider, ValueConsumer
    public interface ComponentI
    The interface ComponentI serves as common supertype for all classes that implements components in this component model.

    Description

    Components in the model are represented by objects and therefore instances of standard Java classes. HOwever, the component virtual machine is defined both as virtual machines operations but also as operations on components that this interface declares and that the abstract class AbstractComponent implements.

    Components offer and require interfaces, and they provide methods to retrieve their required and offered interfaces represented as instances of Class. Components have ports that are used to connect them together through their interfaces. Outbound ports expose required interfaces, while inbound ones expose the offered interfaces. Components can also be queried for the ports that expose some given interface.

    The model include both sequential and concurrent components. As the concurrent ones rely on the Java Executor framework to handle requests with a pool of threads, both sequential and concurrent share the same protocol to execute requests: a handleRequest method capable of executing a Callable task. Tasks then call methods on the object that implement the component; these methods represent the services that the component offers.

    A plug-in facility eases the definition of reusable component services and behaviours. Operations to add and remove plug-ins are therefore provided as well as methods used in the internal management of plug-ins and their life-cycle between plug-in and component objects.

    Logging and tracing facilities are also provided to ease the programming and the debugging of component-based applications. Logging entries can be made visible in logging windows and can be stored in logging files for post-mortem analysis. Tracing entries are meant to be shown on windows.

    Created on : 2012-11-06

    Author:
    Jacques Malenfant

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Interface Description
      static interface  ComponentI.ComponentService<V>
      The interface ComponentService is meant to group under a same interface all of the requests that return results for this component.
      static interface  ComponentI.ComponentTask
      The interface ComponentTask is meant to group under a same interface all of the tasks for this component.
      static interface  ComponentI.FComponentService<T>
      The interface FComponentService is a functional interface allowing to use Java 8 lambda-expressions to create service tasks to be submitted to components.
      static interface  ComponentI.FComponentTask
      The interface FComponentTask is a functional interface allowing to use Java 8 lambda-expressions to create service tasks to be submitted to components.

      • hasSerialisedExecution

        boolean hasSerialisedExecution()
        return true if the component guarantees a serialised execution of its services.

        In the baseline definition, this returns true if the component has its own threads and if the total number of threads is exactly one. A component can guarantee its serialised execution in other ways and then should redefine the method for example, by making all externally callable services implemented by synchronised methods.

        A component that has a serialised execution is in fact a thread-safe monitor.

        Contract

         pre    true            // no precondition.
 post   true            // no postcondition.
        Returns:
        true if the component guarantees a serialised execution of its services.

      • start

        void start()
    throws ComponentStartException
        start the component; this method is automatically called by the component virtual machine after all components have been initialised and the component calls in turn its own inner components. Implementations of this method must always return the control.

        Contract

         pre    isInitialised()
 post   isStarted()
        Throws:
        ComponentStartException - to do.

      • execute

        void execute()
      throws java.lang.Exception
        execute a task on the component after all components have been started; this method is automatically called by the component virtual machine after all components have been started and the component calls in turn its own inner components. Implementations of this method can keep the control as long as they wish (contrary to start) but they need to begin by a call to super if inner components also have an execute method to be called; it is the responsibility of programmers to make sure that this does not provoke deadlocks.

        Contract

         pre    isStarted()
 post   true            // no postcondition.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - to do.

      • scheduleTaskAtFixedRate

        void scheduleTaskAtFixedRate​(ComponentI.ComponentTask t,
                             long initialDelay,
                             long period,
                             java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit u)
                      throws java.lang.AssertionError,
                             java.util.concurrent.RejectedExecutionException
        schedule a ComponentTask that becomes enabled first after the given initial delay, and subsequently with the given period; that is executions will commence after initialDelay then initialDelay+period, then initialDelay + 2 * period, and so on. If any execution of the task encounters an exception, subsequent executions are suppressed. Otherwise, the task will only terminate via cancellation or termination of the executor. If any execution of this task takes longer than its period, then subsequent executions may start late, but will not concurrently execute.

        Contract

         pre    isStarted()
 pre    canScheduleTasks()
 pre    t != null && initialDelay >= 0 && period > 0 && u != null
 post   true            // no postcondition.
        Parameters:
        t - task to be scheduled.
        initialDelay - delay after which the task begins to run.
        period - period between successive executions.
        u - time unit in which the initial delay and the period are expressed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.AssertionError - if the preconditions are not satisfied.
        java.util.concurrent.RejectedExecutionException - if the task cannot be scheduled for execution.

      • scheduleTaskAtFixedRate

                      throws java.lang.AssertionError,
                             java.util.concurrent.RejectedExecutionException
        schedule a ComponentTask that becomes enabled first after the given initial delay, and subsequently with the given period; that is executions will commence after initialDelay then initialDelay+period, the initialDelay + 2 * period, and so on. If any execution of the task encounters an exception, subsequent executions are suppressed. Otherwise, the task will only terminate via cancellation or termination of the executor. If any execution of this task takes longer than its period, then subsequent executions may start late, but will not concurrently execute.

        Contract

         pre    isStarted()
 pre    validExecutorServiceIndex(executorServiceIndex)
 pre    isSchedulable(executorServiceIndex)
 pre    t != null && initialDelay >= 0 && period > 0 && u != null
 post   true            // no postcondition.
        Parameters:
        executorServiceIndex - index of the executor service that will run the task.
        t - task to be scheduled.
        initialDelay - delay after which the task begins to run.
        period - period between successive executions.
        u - time unit in which the initial delay and the period are expressed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.AssertionError - if the preconditions are not satisfied.
        java.util.concurrent.RejectedExecutionException - if the task cannot be scheduled for execution.

                             long initialDelay,
                             long period,
                             java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit u)
                      throws java.lang.AssertionError,
                             java.util.concurrent.RejectedExecutionException

If any execution of this task takes longer than its period, then subsequent executions may start late, but will not concurrently execute.

                        java.lang.String code)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        insert a piece of code at the end of the specified component service.

        Contract

         pre    serviceName != null
 pre    parametersCanonicalClassNames != null
 pre    code != null
 post   true            // no postcondition.
        Parameters:
        serviceName - name of the service method to be modified.
        parametersCanonicalClassNames - names of the types of the parameters of the method.
        code - code to be inserted.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - to do.
